title: More Crestone advisers on the march
text:
The former UBS Wealth Management is due to launch as Crestone on October 1. by Sarah Thompson Anthony Macdonald Jake Mitchell Crestone has been hit by an east coast exodus.
Street Talk understands the former UBS Wealth Management has lost a raft of advisers from its Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane offices in recent weeks.
Bell Potter has nabbed Andrew Jeffery, Stolle Sergis and Chris Matthews in Sydney, with more Crestone recruits expected to follow, while Patrick Regan and Charlie Cropper have joined Morgan Stanley.
Ben Potter has left the Melbourne office to join Escala Partners, which was set up by a number of former UBS Wealth advisers in 2013, led by Percival "Pep" Perry.
This comes after Street Talk revealed William Douglass and James Mapledoram had defected from the Crestone Brisbane office to Koda Capital, while Craig Emmanuel joined Morgan Stanley.
Crestone is due to launch on October 1 after the announcement of a management buyout of UBS Australia's wealth division in May.
Street Talk first revealed UBS Wealth advisers were working on an MBO in February, which came after the firm decided to stop servicing clients that had less than $1 million invested..
News of the departures comes after Crestone chief executive Mike Chisholm said that he had received indications from all of UBS wealth Management's advisers that they were "keen" to join Crestone.
 "There are roughly 100 advisers currently employed at UBS Wealth Management and we have now received indications from 100 per cent of them that they are also keen to come over to Crestone," Chisholm said in May.
